questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to an outpatient clinic for a routine visit. The patient was diagnosed with HIV infection 2 years ago. Current medications include emtricitabine, tenofovir, and dolutegravir. The patient is found to have persistently elevated HIV-1 levels despite being on highly active antiretroviral therapy. Enfuvirtide is added to the patient’s treatment regimen. Which of the following side effects is this patient at greatest risk of developing with this new medication?
questions.solution:
This patient is started on enfuvirtide, which is associated with injection site reactions such as erythema, induration, as well as nodule and cyst formation.  

Antiretroviral therapy (ART) is initiated at the diagnosis of HIV infection. It typically consists of a 3-drug regimen, consisting of 2 nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs) and an integrase inhibitor, to prevent resistance. There are newer classes of HIV medication that have been developed to address treatment-resistant strains of HIV.    

Entry inhibitors, also known as fusion inhibitors, are examples of such drugs. These medications are given to patients who show replication of HIV despite ongoing ART.    

In particular, enfuvirtide acts as a viral entry inhibitor through the binding of the viral gp41 protein, which is involved in viral fusion with T-cells. It is given as a subcutaneous injection. Unlike other HIV medications which are active against HIV-1 and HIV-2, enfuvirtide is only active against HIV-1. Its main side effects are injection site reaction and an increased risk of bacterial infections, such as pneumonia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Increased creatine kinase (CK) levels:
Incorrect: The integrase inhibitors are associated with myopathy and increased CK levels. Examples include bictegravir, dolutegravir, elvitegravir, and raltegravir. They block the integration of the HIV genome into the host cell chromosome through reversible inhibition of HIV integrase.     
❌ Vivid dreams:
Incorrect: Vivid dreams are most commonly associated with efavirenz, which is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI). NNRTIs inhibit viral reverse transcriptase. Additional NNRTIs include delavirdine, efavirenz, and nevirapine. Medications in this class are all associated with rash and hepatotoxicity.   
❌ Bone marrow suppression:
Incorrect: Bone marrow suppression is associated with the use of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs). NRTIs competitively inhibit nucleotides from binding to reverse transcriptase, thereby terminating DNA chain elongation. Examples of NRTIs include abacavir, didanosine, emtricitabine, lamivudine, stavudine, tenofovir, and zidovudine. These medications can also cause peripheral neuropathy, lactic acidosis, and pancreatitis.  
❌ Hyperglycemia:
Incorrect: Hyperglycemia is most commonly seen with protease inhibitors, such as atazanavir, indinavir, lopinavir, ritonavir, and saquinavir. These medications block viral protease, thereby preventing the cleaving of HIV mRNA and viral maturation. Protease inhibitors are also associated with gastrointestinal intolerance and lipodystrophy.  
✅ Injection site reaction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two-months ago, the patient was diagnosed with HIV infection and started on combined antiretroviral therapy. Recently, the patient began experiencing anxiety and difficulty concentrating at work. The patient is concerned that they may end up losing their job. The patient has recently been having intense dreams that “feel as if they were real.” The patient does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or illicit substances. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with difficulty concentrating at work, anxiety, and vivid dreams, which are most likely due to efavirenz-induced central nervous system (CNS) toxicity.

Efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) often used as a part of highly active antiretroviral therapy in patients with HIV infection.

The most important adverse effects of efavirenz involve the CNS. They include dizziness, impaired concentration, dysphoria, vivid or disturbing dreams, and insomnia. Patients on efavirenz can also develop a rash during the first few weeks of treatment that subsequently resolves spontaneously and rarely requires drug discontinuation. Other side effects include headaches, increased hepatic transaminases, and elevated serum cholesterol. Finally, efavirenz and delavirdine are contraindicated during pregnancy as they can cause congenital malformations in the fetus.  

Option Analysis

❌ Enfuvirtide:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide inhibits viral entry into the cell by binding to the gp41 protein. The medication can cause skin reactions at the injection site but does not typically cause central nervous system toxicity.  
❌ Nevirapine:
Incorrect: Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor that is known to cause hepatic necrosis and serious cutaneous reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis). However, it does not typically affect the central nervous system.  
❌ Didanosine:
Incorrect: Didanosine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) that can cause pancreatitis, presumably due to the chronic accumulation of toxic metabolic products. However, didanosine and other NRTIs do not typically cause central nervous system toxicity.  
❌ Lopinavir:
Incorrect: Lopinavir is a protease inhibitor. Common side effects include hyperglycemia, gastrointestinal irritation (e.g. nausea, diarrhea), and lipodystrophy. The medication does not typically cause central nervous system toxicity.  
✅ Efavirenz:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Six months ago, the patient was diagnosed with HIV infection and started on combined antiretroviral therapy. The patient’s medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory studies show a decrease in the CD4 count and an increase in viral load despite ongoing treatment. The patient is switched to a new treatment regimen, which includes a drug that acts by preventing viral DNA synthesis without needing to undergo intracellular phosphorylation. Which of the following medications is most likely part of this patient’s new treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
This patient was most likely started on a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI).

NNRTIs (e.g. efavirenz, delavirdine, nevirapine) are noncompetitive viral reverse transcriptase inhibitors that bind to an allosteric regulatory site on reverse transcriptase. Unlike nucleotide/nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), NNRTIs do not require intracellular phosphorylation for activation.

NNRTIs are used as a part of highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART), which is a combination drug therapy used in the treatment of HIV infection. NNRTIs are rarely used alone since HIV quickly develops resistance to them by point mutation of the reverse transcriptase enzyme. Moreover, these medications have no effect on the completed proviral DNA already incorporated into CD4+ cells. As a result, NNRTIs can slow down disease progression but cannot cure cells that have already been infected.

Side effects include hepatotoxicity (nevirapine), central nervous system toxicity (e.g. insomnia, mood disturbances), vivid dreams (efavirenz), and hypersensitivity reactions (e.g. Stevens-Johnson syndrome).
 

Option Analysis

❌ Emtricitabine:
Incorrect: Emtricitabine inhibits viral DNA synthesis through antagonism of viral reverse transcriptase. However, emtricitabine needs to undergo intracellular phosphorylation before being able to impart its antiviral effects.  
✅ Delavirdine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Raltegravir:
Incorrect: Integrase is an enzyme that helps incorporate the HIV genome into the host chromosome. Integrase inhibitors (e.g. raltegravir) reversibly inhibit HIV integrase. They do not directly inhibit viral DNA synthesis.  
❌ Ritonavir:
Incorrect: Protease is an HIV enzyme that cleaves the polypeptide products of HIV mRNA into their functional parts. Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor and does not directly inhibit viral DNA synthesis.  
❌ Enfuvirtide:
Incorrect: Enfuvirtide is a fusion inhibitor that blocks HIV attachment, penetration, and uncoating. The medication binds to the gp41 subunit of the HIV envelope glycoprotein, thereby preventing conformational changes and inhibiting viral fusion with T-cells.

questions.text: A pathologist is reviewing skin biopsy slides under a microscope. She identifies a neural crest cell derivative that produces pigment to shield the body from ultraviolet radiation. Within which layer of the skin is this cell type located?
questions.solution:
Melanocytes are found within hair follicles and the stratum basale of the epidermis. These cells produce a protein pigment called melanin, which ranges in color from black to reddish yellow and provides skin and hair with pigmentation. It also protects the skin and eyes against ultraviolet radiation and photodamage.  

Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells, stem cells originating from the embryonic ectoderm germ layer. During embryonic development, melanoblasts (precursor cells to melanocytes) travel peripherally along nerve branches to reach the dermis and the epidermis. While traveling to their final destination, melanoblasts multiply in number and sequentially express additional genes that result in their maturation into melanocytes. Due to this migratory process, melanocytes may be present in the dermis during fetal development but not after birth.  



Option Analysis

❌ Stratum lucidum:
Incorrect: Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and produce melanin, a pigment that protects the body from ultraviolet radiation. Melanocytes are located within the stratum basale and hair follicles. The stratum lucidum contains dead keratinocytes.  
❌ Stratum granulosum:
Incorrect: Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and produce melanin, a pigment that protects the body from ultraviolet radiation. Melanocytes are located within the stratum basale and hair follicles. In contrast, the stratum granulosum is composed of keratinocytes.  
✅ Stratum basale:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Papillary dermis  :
Incorrect: Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and produce melanin, a pigment that protects the body from ultraviolet radiation. Although dermal melanocytes can be seen during fetal development, they are not present after birth. Melanocytes pass through the dermis during fetal development to reach the epidermis.
❌ Hypodermis:
Incorrect: Melanocytes are derived from neural crest cells and produce melanin, a pigment that protects the body against ultraviolet radiation. Although dermal melanocytes can be seen during fetal development, they are not typically present after birth. Melanocytes pass through the dermis during fetal development to reach the epidermis.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man comes to the office because of severe generalized pruritus and blisters. The pruritus began a month ago, followed by multiple tense blisters over his body two weeks later. Some of the blisters ruptured, causing moist erosions. Past medical history is significant for Parkinson disease and hypertension. Current medications include levodopa/carbidopa and lisinopril. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple 1 to 3 cm tense bullae as shown:  


Reproduced from Flickr  
Which of the following histological findings will be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with an eczematous prodrome followed by the appearance of multiple tense, pruritic bullae all over the body is suffering from bullous pemphigoid (BP), a chronic, relapsing-remitting autoimmune blistering skin disease.

BP results from a type II hypersensitivity reaction where IgG antibodies are formed against the hemidesmosomal proteins (bullous pemphigoid antigen 2, collagen type XVII) of the basement membrane, causing the separation of dermis and epidermis and resultant subepidermal blisters. It is associated with neurological disorders (e.g., Parkinson disease, dementia, bipolar disorder) and malignancies. It typically presents in older adults with a pre-bullous prodrome of urticaria or eczema-like pruritic skin lesions that can last for weeks to months. This is followed by the development of severe pruritic, tense bullae (negative Nikolsky sign) typically in the flexural surfaces, groin, and axilla, but the condition can involve the whole body. In contrast to pemphigus vulgaris, mucosal involvement (e.g. intraoral) is less common. Biopsy of the lesion would reveal eosinophilic spongiosis and subepidermal blisters (unlike intraepidermal blisters in pemphigus vulgaris).

Direct immunofluorescence is highly sensitive and shows a linear pattern at the dermal-epidermal junction. Treatment is by topical or systemic corticosteroids.  

Option Analysis

✅  Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect: This skin biopsy shows a “saw-tooth” shaped dermo-epidermal junction (presence of lymphocytes) and a thickened stratum granulosum – characteristic of lichen planus. It usually presents as pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques. In oral mucosa, it manifests as Wickham striae (reticular white lines). As seen in this patient, the tense pruritic bullae would be seen in a bullous pemphigoid.   
❌  Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect:  This histologic slide demonstrating hyperkeratosis, acanthosis, hypergranulosis, and long rete ridges is suggestive of verruca vulgaris, also known as common warts. The condition usually presents with cauliflower-like papules with a rough, papillomatous, and hyperkeratotic surface, unlike the tense pruritic blisters seen in this patient.   
❌  Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect: This histologic image shows fibrins and neutrophils at the dermal papillae and subepidermal microabscesses, which are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis. This is an autoimmune skin disorder prevalent among gluten-sensitive individuals which presents with intensely pruritic groups of papules and vesicles on extensor elbows or knees. Tense widespread bullae preceded by a prodrome of pruritus is typical of bullous pemphigoid.   
❌  Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  :
Incorrect: This histologic image shows dysplastic keratinocytes with “keratin pearls” involving the full thickness of the epidermis suggestive of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma. It usually appears as 0.5-1.5 cm indurated or firm plaque, papule, or nodule with or without hyperkeratosis and ulceration. Tense pruritic bullae indicate an alternative diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to the office because of a rash on her elbows. The rash appeared three months ago and is intensely pruritic, often awakening her during sleep. She has tried multiple over-the-counter emollients and ointments with minimal improvement. A review of systems reveals mild abdominal pain and greasy, voluminous stools for the past year. The remainder of the history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows groups of papules and vesicles on the elbows bilaterally as shown:  


Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following findings will be seen on direct immunofluorescence microscopy of biopsy specimens of these lesions?

choices.text: Linear IgG deposits at epidermal-dermal junction
Reticular IgG deposits in intercellular space
Granular IgA deposits at the tip of dermal papillae
Linear IgA deposits along the epidermal-dermal junction
Granular IgG, IgM, IgA, and C3 deposits at the epidermal-dermal junction

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with intensely pruritic, papulovesicular eruptions on her elbows associated with a history of abdominal pain and greasy voluminous diarrhea (most likely due to celiac disease) is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), an autoimmune dermatological disease.

Gluten sensitivity in susceptible individuals leads to IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminases found in the gastrointestinal tract. These antibodies can sometimes cross-react with epidermal transglutaminases causing deposition of IgA-transglutaminase complexes in the dermis, triggering the development of multiple pruritic papules and vesicles grouped in “herpetiform" arrangements. The most common sites are elbows, dorsal forearms, knees, scalp, back, and buttocks. In addition to celiac disease, dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with autoimmune thyroiditis, type I diabetes mellitus, and pernicious anemia. Moreover, it is highly prevalent in HLA-DQ2 or HLA-DQ8 haplotypes.

Histopathology of the lesions shows fibrins and neutrophils at the dermal papillae and subepidermal microabscesses. Direct immunofluorescence is the gold standard for diagnosis and reveals granular IgA deposits at the tip of dermal papillae. Treatment options include a gluten-free diet and dapsone.  



Option Analysis

❌ Linear IgG deposits at epidermal-dermal junction  :
Incorrect: Linear IgG deposits at the epidermal-dermal junction on direct immunofluorescence are characteristic of bullous pemphigoid. They result from a type II hypersensitivity reaction where IgG antibodies are formed against the hemidesmosomes of the basement membrane. The condition typically presents with intensely pruritic, tense bullae on flexor surfaces, unlike the papulovesicular eruption in this patient.  
❌ Reticular IgG deposits in intercellular space  :
Incorrect: Direct immunofluorescence revealing reticular IgG deposits in the intercellular space is characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris, a type II hypersensitivity reaction in which IgG antibodies are formed against desmoglein. It usually manifests as flaccid bullae, ulcers, and mucosal erosions. The presence of papules and vesicles on extensor surfaces is atypical.  
✅ Granular IgA deposits at the tip of dermal papillae  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Linear IgA deposits along the epidermal-dermal junction  :
Incorrect: Linear IgA deposits along the epidermal-dermal junction are typical for bullous dermatosis, a rare autoimmune blistering disorder. Although it also manifests with papules and vesicles (similar to this patient), the presence of gastrointestinal symptoms (indicative of gluten-sensitive enteropathy) is characteristically absent in bullous dermatosis.  
❌ Granular IgG, IgM, IgA, and C3 deposits at the epidermal-dermal junction  :
Incorrect: Granular IgG, IgM, IgA, and C3 deposits at the epidermal-dermal junctions are characteristically found in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). These patients have a malar rash (sparing nasolabial folds) and discoid lesions, along with constitutional symptoms, arthritis, photosensitivity, and other systemic diseases, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy living in the Southwest United States is brought to the office by his parent because of a nonpruritic rash on his hands for the past two days. He has also had mild shortness of breath, dry cough, and malaise since last week. He has no prior medical conditions and does not take any medication. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and he has not traveled recently. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 115/80 mmHg. Examination of the hands reveals the following:  


Reproduced from Flickr  
Lung auscultation reveals bilateral coarse crackles. Chest x-ray shows patchy, non-segmental bilateral opacities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with multiple nonpruritic targetoid lesions on the dorsum of his hands is consistent with erythema multiforme (EM), most likely due to a T-cell mediated cytotoxic immune response to Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection (dyspnea, dry cough, low-grade fever, chest x-ray demonstrating opacities).

EM is a type IV hypersensitivity immune-mediated condition that results when the cytotoxic T-cells initiate an inflammatory cascade against the peripherally phagocytosed pathogen (brought to the epidermis), causing epithelial damage. Common causes include herpes simplex virus infection (HSV), Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection, medications (e.g., sulfonamides, antiepileptics, beta-lactams), malignancy, and collagen vascular disease. EM typically presents as nonpruritic papules, macules, and vesicles with multiple rings and a dusky center, with a red inflammatory zone surrounded by a pale halo at the periphery. It usually affects the skin of extremities, face, trunk, neck, and mucous membranes of the mouth and genitals.

Diagnosis is clinical, but a biopsy can confirm the diagnosis in atypical cases. Histopathology typically reveals basal vacuolar cell degeneration, perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate, and epidermal necrosis. It usually self-resolves within 1-2 weeks, but identification and removal of the trigger are of utmost importance.  

Option Analysis

❌ Urticaria  :
Incorrect: Acute urticaria, which results from mast cell degranulation, presents with pruritic, well-demarcated, erythematous plaques that usually last no more than 12 hours. Nonpruritic papules and macules with multiple rings and a dusky center would be atypical.
❌ Erythema migrans  :
Incorrect: Erythema migrans is an early manifestation of Lyme disease that presents with a “bull’s eye” rash 1-2 weeks after an infected tick bite. This patient’s history is not significant for travel to Lyme endemic areas. Moreover, his respiratory symptoms are suggestive of atypical pneumonia.  
❌ Erythema marginatum:
Incorrect: Erythema marginatum is found in association with acute rheumatic fever secondary to a streptococcal throat infection. It presents a pink, nonpruritic rash with a pale center and  serpiginous margins. It most commonly occurs on the trunk, spreads centrifugally, and can disappear within hours to days on its own. This patient has no history of a sore throat and instead has a respiratory infection.  
✅ Erythema multiforme:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Steven-Johnson syndrome  :
Incorrect: Steven-Johnson syndrome (SJS) presents with erythematous macules, vesicles, and bullae with epidermal necrosis and sloughing 4-28 days following exposure to a trigger (e.g., trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole, lamotrigine). Mucosal involvement is commonly seen. Although targetoid lesions can be seen, SJS is usually associated with abnormal vital signs. This patient’s vitals are within normal limits.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of a rash that has been present the past two months. During this time, she has noticed red areas on her upper chest that slowly enlarge, then partially heal, leaving scar-like areas in the periphery. The patient has also been experiencing fevers and joint pains. Medical history is significant for primary essential hypertension, which is well controlled on amlodipine. She takes no other medications and has no allergies. The patient’s temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg. Physical exam shows discrete, erythematous, indurated plaques, covered with adherent scale, localized to the upper chest, as pictured:  



 Reproduced from: U.S. National Library of Medicine 
*Dark red spots are biopsy sites  

Biopsy histopathology shows hyperkeratosis, follicular plugging, and a mononuclear T-cell infiltrate. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Cutaneous lupus erythematosus describes the broad group of cutaneous lesions that are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Cutaneous lupus erythematosus encompasses both the lupus erythematosus-specific skin diseases (malar rash, discoid lupus) as well as the lupus nonspecific skin diseases, including nonscarring alopecia and vascular abnormalities like livedo reticularis and Raynaud's phenomenon.  



Among patients who present with isolated cutaneous lupus erythematosus, approximately 10% will be diagnosed with SLE within 5 years. This association highlights the fact that skin manifestations may be the earliest signs of SLE.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cutaneous lupus erythematosus:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Hepatitis C infection:
Incorrect: Hepatitis C infection has been associated with the skin condition lichen planus, in which autoreactive T lymphocytes attack basal keratinocytes in the skin. Lesions are purple, planar, polygonal, pruritic papules or plaques.  
❌ Psoriasis:
Incorrect: Psoriasis is a chronic, intermittently relapsing disease caused by aberrant T cell and keratinocyte function. Skin lesions are characterized by sharply demarcated, erythematous, silvery, scaly plaques on the elbows, knees, and scalp.  
❌ Dermatomyositis:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is a multisystem autoimmune connective tissue disease characterized by symmetric, proximal inflammatory myopathy. The pathognomonic lesion is the heliotrope rash: a violaceous, edematous periorbital edema that may be slightly scaly.  
❌ Polymyositis:
Incorrect: Polymyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by symmetric proximal muscle weakness and elevated creatine kinase (a muscle enzyme). Skin lesions are not typically associated with polymyositis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the office because of numerous pigmented bumps over his chin and neck for the past six months. The rash is associated with mild pain and tenderness and did not improve with emollients or cleansers. The rest of the patient’s medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown below. He is a Black man of Haitian descent, and the hair in this region of his chin and neck is coarse and tightly curled. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?


Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Penetration of hair in interfollicular skin
Horny plugs in hair follicle orifices

questions.solution:
This man’s presents with firm, hyperpigmented papules over the area of the neck and chin for the past six months; this presentation is consistent with pseudofolliculitis barbae (PB), an inflammatory disease of the hair-bearing area. PB is also colloquially referred to as "razor bumps," "shave bumps," or "ingrown hairs."  

PB occurs commonly among individuals with coarse, tightly curled hair, which creates short, sharp-ended hair emerging from the hair follicles; the condition is common among Black individuals. The stretching of the skin during shaving can cause the retraction of hair in the follicles, inhibiting its growth back to the surface. A cutaneous inflammatory response then results secondary to the penetration of hair in the interfollicular epidermis and dermis, manifesting as firm papules at the site of the embedded hair.    

PB is mainly a cosmetic concern but can become complicated with secondary bacterial infection (pustules), keloid formation, and hyperpigmentation over time. Diagnosis is based on clinical appearance, and definitive treatment is achieved by permanent discontinuation of shaving or switching to other hair removal methods such as waxing or laser hair removal. 

Option Analysis

❌ Inflammation of hair follicles:
Incorrect: Folliculitis is the inflammation of hair follicles that usually presents acutely with erythematous papules and pustules. Bacterial infection by Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause. This patient’s chronic history of firm papules suggests a different diagnosis. 
❌ Blockage of pilosebaceous subunits:
Incorrect: Acne vulgaris a chronic skin disease that results from blockage and inflammation of pilosebaceous subunits; it can present as noninflammatory comedones, papules, pustules, or nodules. The pigmented and firm papules seen in this patient would be atypical. 
✅ Penetration of hair in interfollicular skin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Horny plugs in hair follicle orifices:
Incorrect: Keratosis pilaris is a genetic disorder that results in formation in horny plugs in hair follicle orifices. It commonly manifests in childhood and adolescents with spiny keratotic papules on the proximal extensor surfaces of arms or thighs. Neck and chin involvement with firm hyperpigmented papules would be atypical. 
❌ Complication of an autoimmune disease:
Incorrect: Cutaneous sarcoidosis can present with multiple papules or plaques, which may be hyperpigmented or hypopigmented. However, the embedded beard hair seen in this patient is not typically present.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the office because of oral pain. The pain has been constant for several weeks and worsens with chewing and swallowing food. He also reports the development of non-pruritic, tender skin sores on his arms and legs, which occurred two weeks following the onset of the oral pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. He has been working as a gardener in California for 20 years. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mmHg. Physical examination shows multiple erosions and flaccid bullae on the extremities and buccal mucosa. When lateral pressure is applied on the bullae, the overlying layer easily slips off, revealing an erythematous base. Direct immunofluorescence on perilesional skin specimens of this patient is shown.  


Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
Antibodies against which of the following antigens is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with multiple painful mucosal erosions, non-pruritic flaccid cutaneous bullae, and positive Nikolsky sign (separation of the epidermis by light friction), together with direct immunofluorescence (DIF) microscopy revealing reticular IgG deposits in the intercellular space, is most likely suffering from pemphigus vulgaris.

Pemphigus vulgaris is a type II hypersensitivity reaction whereby IgG antibodies are formed against desmoglein-1 and desmoglein-3. Desmogleins are desmosomal proteins that connect keratinocytes within the stratum spinosum, and therefore, disruption of this protein results in the detachment of keratinocytes from one another. The specific triggers are unclear, but it is thought there may be genetic susceptibility, in addition to a potential association with ultraviolet radiation and exposure to certain drugs (e.g., penicillamine and captopril). It classically affects middle-aged adults (unlike bullous pemphigoid, which typically affects older adults) and can be fatal. It usually manifests as mucosal blisters and erosions affecting the oral cavity, conjunctiva, nose, and anus. Cutaneous involvement presents with painful, non-pruritic flaccid bullae and blisters on the extremities and trunk with positive Nikolsky sign.

Diagnosis is based on clinical presentation, histopathology, and immunofluorescence. The lesion biopsy shows intraepidermal cleavage with acantholysis (keratinocytes detachment) in the suprabasal epidermis and the characteristic tombstoning of the dermo-epidermal junction. Immunofluorescence shows reticular IgG deposits in the intercellular space. Treatment is by systemic steroids.  



Option Analysis

✅ Desmoglein  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemidesmosome:
Incorrect:  Bullous pemphigoid, a type II hypersensitivity reaction, results from IgG antibodies against the hemidesmosomes of the basement membrane. It typically presents with intensely pruritic, tense bullae on flexor surfaces, unlike the flaccid, non-pruritic bullae in this patient. Moreover, direct immunofluorescence typically shows linear IgG deposits at the epidermal-dermal junction, in contrast to the net-like reticular pattern in this patient.  
❌ Centromere  :
Incorrect: Anti-centromere antibodies are characteristic of systemic sclerosis, which usually presents with skin thickening and hardening, mainly involving the fingers, hands, and face. Flaccid bullae with a positive Nikolsky sign would be atypical.  
❌ Ribonucleoprotein:
Incorrect: Mixed connective tissue disease, a generalized systemic disorder, is characterized by anti-U1 ribonucleoprotein antibodies in combination with clinical features of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), scleroderma, and polymyositis. This patient’s presentation with cutaneous bullae is suggestive of a different diagnosis.  
❌ Double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid  :
Incorrect: Antibodies against double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (anti-dsDNA) are SLE characteristics. These patients present with a malar rash (sparing nasolabial folds) and discoid lesions with constitutional symptoms, arthritis, photosensitivity, and other systemic diseases, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, granular IgG, IgM, IgA, and C3 deposit at epidermal-dermal junctions on direct immunofluorescence.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of a sensation of “dryness and tightness” in the skin. The symptoms began six months ago. She has tried vaseline lotion but reports that it does not improve her symptoms. Past medical history is notable for allergies and asthma, for which she is currently taking loratadine and uses an albuterol inhaler. She smokes half-a-pack of cigarettes per day. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F) and blood pressure is 125/71 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for thickened skin over the face, hands, and forearms. There is reduced range of motion in the bilateral hands.  Skin on the chest, abdomen, and back appear normal. Inspection of the patient’s hands reveals the following finding:  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following additional symptoms would most likely be found on this patient's history and physical examination?

choices.text: Resolution of symptoms with smoking cessation

questions.solution:
The patient has limited cutaneous systemic scleroderma. This variant of scleroderma is characterized by mild internal organ involvement and generally affects only skin of the face and distal extremities.  

In terms of skin findings, the condition can cause calcinosis cutis (cutaneous and subcutaneous deposition of calcium salts) and Raynaud phenomenon (discoloration of the fingers in cold temperatures secondary to vasospasm). Patients can present with sclerodactyly (tightening and thickening of skin on the hands) and telangiectasias (small dilated blood vessels occurring near the skin/mucosa surface). Over time, vasospasm can lead to tissue ischemia and present with digit ulcers similar to the one shown in the image. Internal organ involvement is largely limited to esophageal dysfunction, which can manifest as gastroesophageal reflux disease.

The key symptoms of limited cutaneous systemic scleroderma can be remembered with the acronym CREST: Calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, Esophageal dysfunction, Sclerodactyly, and Telangiectasia.      

Option Analysis

❌ Constipation and bowel dysmotility:
Incorrect: Constipation secondary to bowel dysmotility is seen in diffuse scleroderma. This condition affects visceral organs including the lungs, heart, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys. In addition, this condition presents with thickening of the skin throughout the body. In contrast, this patient has skin thickening only in the face and distal upper extremities.   
❌ Resolution of symptoms with smoking cessation:
Incorrect: This describes thromboangiitis obliterans (also known as Buerger disease). It is a vasculitis seen in heavy smokers, which can lead to gangrene and autoamputation of the digits. Although this patient has a smoking history and finger ulcers, thromboangiitis obliterans would not explain the thickened skin and reduced range of motion.   
❌ Calf pain exacerbated by walking:
Incorrect: This is seen in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). PAD can diminish blood flow to the extremities, causing tissue necrosis and ulceration. However, ulcers secondary to PAD are most often found in the lower extremities. In addition, PAD would not account for the patient’s skin thickening and reduced range of motion.  
✅ Calcium deposition at the elbow:
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Corneal scarring and blurred vision  :
Incorrect: Sjögren syndrome presents with dry mouth, dry eyes, and systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, myalgias). The condition reduces tear production, which predisposes patients to corneal injury. In rare cases, it can contribute to vasculitis and cause skin ulceration. However, it would be atypical for Sjogren syndrome to present with skin thickening or reduce joint motion in the hands.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of an exquisitely painful rash on the right side of his chest wall. He states it started with a burning sensation in the same region over the past several days that mildly improved with acetaminophen, but then he began noticing the formation of “blisters” in the region. He states he had a fever and feelings of malaise several days ago. Past medical history is significant for chronic kidney disease secondary to diabetic nephropathy and renal transplantation two months ago. Current medications include insulin and cyclosporine. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings are shown.  


Reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following terminologies best describes these skin lesions?
questions.solution:
This patient’s raised lesions with <1 cm fluid-containing blisters in a dermatomal distribution are called vesicles. Given his history of immunosuppression (renal transplantation), herpes zoster is the most likely diagnosis.

Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, results from reactivation of the latent varicella-zoster virus that gained access to sensory ganglia at the time of primary infection (chickenpox). Herpes zoster is a painful, unilateral vesicular eruption that is usually restricted by dermatomal distribution. Zoster characteristically presents with a prodrome of fever, malaise, and excruciating burning pain, followed by the outbreak of vesicles that appear over the following three to five days.

Other macroscopic morphologies of common dermatological lesions are described below:  



Option Analysis

❌ Wheal  :
Incorrect: A wheal is characterized as an itchy, erythematous, raised plaque with well-defined margins and a pale center. It results from type I hypersensitivity reaction causing dermal edema and is seen in urticaria. Painful vesicular eruptions, as seen in this patient, are not wheals.  
❌ Macules  :
Incorrect: Macules are described as flat, <1 cm changes in skin color, such as freckles. Instead, this patient has raised lesions with blisters.  
❌ Papules  :
Incorrect: Papules are defined as <1 cm solid elevated skin lesions with no fluid. It is characteristically seen in acne or a mole. This patient has fluid-containing lesions.  
❌ Plaques  :
Incorrect: Plaques are elevated, solid skin lesions >1cm in diameter and are most commonly associated with psoriasis.  
✅ Vesicles  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl comes to the office for an evaluation of a rash. The rash has been on her abdomen for the past week and is nonpruritic. She returned from a trip to Puerto Rico 10 days ago. She has no other specific complaints at this visit. Past medical history is significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin. The patient’s mother has Hashimoto thyroiditis, and her sister has severe facial acne. Vitals are within normal limits. A physical examination of the rash is shown below. Which of the following best describes the individual lesions of this patient's rash? 


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with tinea versicolor, which typically presents with hypopigmented or hyperpigmented, flat, <1 cm lesions known as macules, especially on the chest and back. The majority of tinea versicolor is caused by the fungus Malassezia globosa. These yeasts are typically found on the human skin and become troublesome only under certain circumstances, such as in warm and humid environments (e.g. Puerto Rico).  

Other macroscopic morphologies of common dermatological lesions with examples are described below.



Option Analysis

❌ Wheals:
Incorrect: Wheals are characterized by itchy, erythematous, raised plaques with well-defined margins and pale centers. They result from a type I hypersensitivity reaction causing dermal edema, and they are seen in urticaria. The flat, <1 cm changes in skin color seen in this patient are not wheals. 
✅ Macules:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Papules:
Incorrect: Papules are defined as <1 cm solid elevated skin lesions with no oozing fluid. They are characteristically seen in acne or moles. The flat, <1 cm changes in skin color seen in this patient are not papules. 
❌ Plaques:
Incorrect: Plaques are elevated, solid skin lesions >1 cm in diameter and are most commonly seen in association with psoriasis. The flat, <1 cm changes in skin color seen in this patient are not plaques. 
❌ Patches:
Incorrect: A patch is a flat skin lesion > 1 cm in size that differs in color from surrounding skin (e.g. congenital nevus). The flat, <1 cm changes in skin color seen in this patient are not patches.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the office for the evaluation of a sunburn. He had just returned from a week-long vacation to Florida, where his activities included swimming in the ocean, playing football at the shore, and river rafting. On the 2nd day, he started developing painful redness on his extremities and face, after which he began applying sunscreen before going out in the sun. His condition did not improve, and his skin started peeling off and developing blisters in the affected areas by the 4th day. The patient is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a fair-skinned adolescent with tender, blanching erythema and blisters on his shoulder and extremities as shown:  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons   

Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Fourth-degree burns extending to deep tissues

questions.solution:
This young boy with extensive exposure to sunlight during vacation has developed sunburn. The clinical findings of tender, blanching erythema, together with blister formation and peeling of skin, make superficial partial-thickness burn the most likely diagnosis.

Superficial partial-thickness burns involve the epidermis and papillary layer of the dermis. The problematic areas are usually painful to touch, erythematous, weeping, and blanch with pressure. These can be differentiated from first-degree burns by their tendency to form blisters.  


Reproduced from: ">Wikimedia Commons  
The healing process usually takes 7 to 21 days, depending on the total body surface area (TBSA) involved in the injury, and scarring is unusual. Supportive management is required and includes appropriate analgesia, cleaning with antiseptic soap, and daily dressing with or without topical antibiotics.  

Option Analysis

❌ First-degree superficial burn  :
Incorrect: A first-degree (superficial) burn involves only the epidermal layer of skin. It typically appears as an erythematous, dry, blanching rash that is painful to touch. Although this patient may have initially developed first-degree burns, his continuous sunlight exposure extended the damage into the superficial (papillary) dermis, resulting in the formation of blisters.  
✅ Second-degree superficial partial-thickness burn  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Second-degree deep partial-thickness burn  :
Incorrect: Deep partial-thickness burns extend into the deeper dermis and are characterized by varying mottled colorization (yellow to cheesy white), blister formation, and damage to the hair follicles. They are painful to pressure only and are usually non-blanchable. This patient’s blisters are blanchable and are tender to touch, making superficial partial-thickness burn more likely.  
❌ Third-degree full-thickness burn  :
Incorrect: Third-degree burn extends through the entire dermis. Affected areas appear white, leathery, and charred. Blisters are not a typical feature, and penetration into the reticular layer damages the sensory nerve endings; hence the wound is not (or is minimally) painful.  
❌ Fourth-degree burns extending to deep tissues  :
Incorrect: Fourth-degree burns are considered those which extend through the skin into underlying soft tissue and include the subcutaneous fat, muscles, and bone. They are relatively painless due to the destruction of nerve endings and appear as dry, charred black lesions with patches of dead skin. This patient’s burn has not breached the skin barrier completely.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents to the office because of a facial rash she has had for nine months. She reports that it waxes and wanes but never entirely resolves. She also reports a tingling and burning sensation over the affected area when she goes out in her garden during the day. She states that her friend noticed that the flushing increased when they had a glass of wine last night. The rash did not improve with the application of high-potency sunblock or other over-the-counter emollients. The patient does not have any muscle weakness or joint pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination findings of her face are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a central, bright red facial rash involving the nasolabial folds, together with papules on the nose and facial flushing with sunlight exposure and alcohol intake; this presentation is consistent with rosacea.    

Rosacea is an inflammatory facial skin disorder that typically affects fair-skinned individuals. The exact etiology is unknown, but the condition is believed to result from a chronic inflammatory response to cutaneous micro-organisms, ultraviolet radiation, and vascular dysfunction. The symptoms can be exacerbated by alcohol, sunlight, extreme temperatures, spicy foods, and hot beverages. Rosacea can be broadly classified into four phenotypes, as shown in the table below.



Figure A
Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons


Figure B
Retrieved from Wikimedia Commons

Option Analysis

❌ Dermatomyositis:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is proximal extensor muscle inflammatory myopathy that usually presents with characteristic Gottron papules on the hands, a heliotrope rash on the eyelids, and symmetric proximal muscle weakness. Although mild dusky violaceous erythema of the central face may be present, the bright facial erythema seen in this patient is atypical. Additionally, this patient does not have muscle weakness, making dermatomyositis unlikely.  
❌ Systemic lupus erythematosus:
Incorrect: Although systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can present with a facial rash resembling the one seen in this patient, the rash is usually darker, spares the nasolabial folds, and is not aggravated by alcohol intake. Moreover, other findings like joint pains, oral ulcers, and constitutional symptoms are usually present in SLE. 
❌ Seborrheic dermatitis :
Incorrect: Central facial erythema involving the nasolabial folds can be seen in seborrheic dermatitis. However, the characteristic greasy scales of areas such as the scalp, retroauricular area, and eyebrows are not seen in this patient. 
✅ Rosacea:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acne vulgaris :
Incorrect: Acne vulgaris is a chronic skin disease that usually presents as noninflammatory comedones, papules, pustules, or nodules. The absence of comedones in this patient excludes this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2 para 1, at 12 weeks gestation, presents to the emergency department because of sloughing off of the skin and pain in and around the oral cavity. For the past four days, these symptoms were preceded by fever, joint pain, and malaise. She reports mouth and throat pain during swallowing both solids and liquids. She has a history of generalized tonic-clonic seizures and was recently switched to a different medication. She works as a postal carrier and traveled to Massachusetts two months ago to visit her aunt. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg. Physical examination shows an ill-appearing woman with extensive erosions of the oral mucosa and sloughed skin of the face and chest that is tender to touch. Which of the following is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with tender, peeling skin of her face and chest, oral pain, and mucosal erosions following a prodrome of an influenza-like illness is most likely suffering from Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). It was likely triggered by a new medication (such as lamotrigine) for her seizures.

SJS is a severe mucocutaneous type IV hypersensitivity reaction that results from cytotoxic T-cell-mediated destruction of keratinocytes expressing foreign antigens, leading to mucocutaneous erosions, necrosis, and detachment at the basement membrane. Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) is  considered a continuum of SJS. TEN differs in terms of the severity and percentage of the body surface area (BSA) affected:  

  •  SJS affects <10% of the BSA 
  •  SJS-TEN overlap when the affected region is 10-30% of the BSA 
  •  TEN >30% of the BSA 
SJS typically presents 4-28 days after exposure to a trigger, most commonly a drug (e.g., allopurinol, lamotrigine, carbamazepine, sulfonamides, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs). Other associated factors include Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection, vaccinations (rarely), and graft-versus-host disease. The onset is characterized by a prodrome of an influenza-like illness (fever, joint pain, malaise) followed by signs and symptoms of systemic toxicity (e.g., high-grade fever, tachycardia, hypotension, altered level of consciousness) and mucocutaneous eruption. The latter presents as erythematous macules, vesicles, and bullae which rapidly progress to skin sloughing and necrosis and mucosal erosions. Diagnosis is clinical, and management is supportive care with adequate fluid hydration.  

Option Analysis

❌ Herpes simplex virus infection  :
Incorrect: Viral infection caused by herpes simplex virus can lead to erythema multiforme, usually presenting with asymptomatic targetoid lesions. Herpetic vesicles instead of influenza-like symptoms (fever, malaise, joint pain) usually precede the onset of these lesions. This patient has no such rash.  
✅ Medication side-effect  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sun exposure:
Incorrect: Excessive sun exposure can cause sunburn, which presents with tender, blanching erythema, blister formation, and peeling skin. Mucosal erosions, however, are not usually seen.  
❌ Tick bite  :
Incorrect: Ixodes tick bite can lead to the development of erythema migrans (EM), the earliest manifestation of Lyme disease. EM typically presents with a painless “bull’s eye” rash 1-2 weeks after the bite. Although this patient has a history of travel to a Lyme endemic area, her painful and tender mucocutaneous lesions and hemodynamic instability suggest an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Pregnancy  :
Incorrect: Although pregnancy can precipitate inflammatory dermatoses, this usually occurs in the third trimester. The lesions are usually papular or eczematous and start from stretch marks in the periumbilical region. Tenderness and mucosal erosions are not commonly seen.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl comes to the office because of a rash on her forehead. The rash started to appear 3-4 weeks ago and has progressively spread to involve her entire forehead. She also reports being stressed about her upcoming debate competition this week. Past medical history is noncontributory. She recently became sexually active with her boyfriend and started using oral contraceptives for contraception. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus in her father. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows multiple scattered papules on her forehead as shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This adolescent girl with multiple open comedones on her forehead, in the setting of a recent stressor (upcoming debate competition), is most likely suffering from acne vulgaris, a common inflammatory skin disorder affecting hair follicles and sebaceous glands. The underlying etiology is multifactorial and involves the following changes:  
  •  Hyperkeratosis of lower follicular infundibulum 
  •  Increased sebum production from sebaceous glands, stimulated by androgens 
  •  Subsequent proliferation of Cutibacterium acnes (part of normal flora) causing inflammation and development of papules and pustules 
Common predisposing factors include genetic predisposition, hormonal imbalance, infection, medications, psychological stress, and polycystic ovarian syndrome. Treatment options depend on the severity and include retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, antibiotics, and isotretinoin. Acne vulgaris can be categorized into the following 4 types based on severity, as shown in the table below.



Option Analysis

❌ Rosacea:
Incorrect: Rosacea is an inflammatory cutaneous disorder that usually presents with persistent facial flushing, telangiectasia, papules, pustules, and ocular hyperemia. It can be exacerbated by exposure to sunlight, alcohol intake, or eating spicy foods. Rosacea is differentiated from acne vulgaris by the absence of comedones and the presence of telangiectasia in the former.

Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
❌ Sebaceous hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Sebaceous glands enlargement is termed sebaceous hyperplasia. It presents small pale papules with umbilication mainly on the forehead and cheeks. The presence of open comedones favors the diagnosis of acne vulgaris.
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
✅ Acne vulgaris:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hidradenitis suppurativa:
Incorrect: Hidradenitis suppurativa is an inflammatory occlusion of the pilosebaceous subunit that results in the formation of solitary, painful nodules, not papules. Moreover, it usually affects intertriginous areas (e.g., axilla, inguinal, and perineal areas)

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
❌ Drug-induced acne:
Incorrect: Drug-induced acne appears as monomorphic papular lesions, unlike the polymorphous lesions seen in this patient. Moreover, combined oral contraceptives do not promote acne but can improve it by inhibiting androgen synthesis. Common examples that can cause drug-induced acne include glucocorticoids, phenytoin, lithium, and isoniazid.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old woman comes to her primary care provider for evaluation of skin patches that are lighter in color than the surrounding skin. Her symptoms began 4-months ago and have progressively worsened. The affected areas are non-painful and non-pruritic. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus and hypothyroidism, for which she is currently taking metformin and levothyroxine, respectively. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 116/73 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Physical examination of the patient’s skin reveals the following:

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal examinations are noncontributory. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Infection of skin by Malassezia furfur
Deposition of disorganized collagen at injury site

questions.solution:
This patient has vitiligo, an acquired condition characterized by the development of irregular patches of depigmented skin. In addition, patients can develop depigmentation of the hair and iris. Vitiligo can be subdivided into non-segmental and segmental vitiligo.

Non-segmental vitiligo tends to affect the extremities (e.g., hands, feet), neck, and head. The lesions are usually symmetrical. Segmental vitiligo tends to affect areas of skin near the spinal cord dorsal roots. The lesions are usually asymmetrical. Both types are caused by the autoimmune destruction of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is associated with other autoimmune disorders, such as type I diabetes mellitus, psoriasis, Graves disease, and Hashimoto thyroiditis.

There are two main treatment approaches. When the affected area is small, cosmetic cover up and topical immune-suppressants can be applied directly to skin. When the affected area is large, systemic immune-suppressants, UV phototherapy, skin-bleaching, and in severe cases, skin grafts, can be tried. Whatever the course of therapy, sunscreen is recommended to prevent darkening of skin areas immediately surrounding the vitiligo lesions and contrasting the depigmentation areas. Moreover, sunscreen can reduce the risk of skin cancer.    

Option Analysis

❌ Impaired melanocyte tyrosinase activity:
Incorrect: Impaired melanocyte tyrosinase activity would hinder melanin production and result in albinism. The condition manifests with diffusely white skin and hair. In contrast, this patient has only patches of hypopigmentation, which is more consistent with vitiligo. Moreover, the symptoms of albinism would be present at birth.  
✅  Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Infection of skin by Malassezia furfur :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes tinea versicolor, which arises secondary to an infection of the skin by the Malassezia fungus. The fungus can degrade lipids, which produces acids that damage melanocytes, ultimately causing hypo- or hyperpigmented lesions. However, skin lesions affected by Malassezia are generally pruritic. 
❌ Deposition of disorganized collagen at injury site:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a keloid, which occurs when there is over-deposition of scar tissue at an injury site. Keloids manifest as firm, rubbery nodules that are elevated from the skin’s surface. In contrast, this patient’s lesions are at the same level as the remaining skin.   
❌ Vasospasm of small vessels :
Incorrect: This answer describes Raynaud phenomenon, which occurs when small blood vessel vasospasms reduces blood supply to the digits. The digits can turn white or blue in color. However, once the inciting trigger has been removed, episodes of Raynaud phenomenon usually resolve within 30-60 minutes. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms have persisted for several months.
